newsitem.title: INDIA: Key questions dog India leadership tussle.
newsitem.headline: Key questions dog India leadership tussle.

text.p: The fear of early polls has become a key issue for India's defeated United Front alliance as it sought on Friday to elect a new leader to replace defeated Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda, alliance officials said.

They said the 15-party coalition, which lost power in a vote of confidence in parliament last week, was moving towards electing a new leader from India's populous northern Hindi-speaking region, the main theatre of electoral battles.
The alliance faces the right-wing Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) as its main opponent in the northern states.
Its chief rival in the southern states was the Congress party, which has offered to support a new United Front government after forcing the fall of Deve Gowda on April 11, alliance officials said.
"With this in view, the next prime minister should be from the north," a senior leader of the influential Left Front, which is part of the United Front, told Reuters.
He said the Left Front, which has 52 of the alliance's 178 lawmakers, was opposed to G.K. Moopanar, leader of Finance Minister P. Chidambaram's Tamil Maanila Congress party.
Moopanar is a former member of the Congress party from the southern state of Tamil Nadu and is widely regarded as the Congress party's unstated choice to succeed Deve Gowda.
The United Front on Friday authorised southern Andhra Pradesh state Chief Minister Chandrababu Naidu to name a new leader after consultations with the leaders of the 15-party coalition.

Among the northern Indian candidates are caretaker Defence Minister Mulayam Singh Yadav, caretaker Railway Minister Ram Vilas Paswan and Bihar state Chief Minister Laloo Prasad Yadav, United Front officials said.
Left Front officials said there was growing consensus for Mulayam Singh Yadav as the new leader.
"He would be our choice, but any other northern leader with a mass base will be a good candidate," one official told Reuters.
Mulayam Singh Yadav is a former chief minister of Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state where the BJP recently formed a local government in alliance with a low-caste Hindu party.
Uttar Pradesh elects 85 lawmakers to the 545-seat lower house of parliament.
Laloo Prasad Yadav is the chief minister of Bihar, India's second most populous state, which sends 54 deputies to parliament.

"Laloo appears to be a weak candidate because of the scandals surrounding his government," a United Front official said, referring to a federal police probe into a $285 million financial incident in Bihar.

Paswan belongs to the lowest Hindu caste, and has strong appeal compared with either the Congress or the BJP, a useful factor in looming polls, against two parties regarded as largely upper caste, officials said.
United Front sources said Naidu's choice of a leader, to be announced on Saturday, would be determined by two factors -- keeping the 15-party United Front together and preparing it for elections.
If Moopanar gets elected as the new leader, the Left Front will walk out of the United Front's decision-making Steering Committee, a senior Left Front official said.
"If we can't come to a decision, we will go to polls under Deve Gowda as caretaker prime minister," said a leader of the Communist Party of India-Marxist, a key constituent of the United Front.
